reviewText:
Burn baby burn! DISCO INFERNO! Burn baby burn!

Yes. Game may have really small community and game network isn't always stable, but I simply cannot give this game a bad recommendation. It's premise, presentation and execution is extremely tight, creating one of the most fun multiplayer experiences you can find. It's really what it says on the tin: robots playing dodgeballl to the awesome retro-chiptune-disco soundtrack and it's so much fun tossing projecticles into others' faces in pleaphora of ways.

Grab your friends, buy a 4-pack and have fun. Dev and his game really deserve more love, judging by their commitment with updates and efforts to keep making the game better. It's a really fun and innocent game and those do not come frequently.

Early Access Review

I don't ordinarily recommend games that are quite so early in development, but I'll make an exception for Robot Roller Derby Disco Dodgeball. This game is absolutely fantastic- it's as fun to play as it is to say. Remember Quake? Well, it feels a lot like Quake, but with robots. In a disco.

reviewText: This game far surpassed any expectations I had upon purchasing it. When I buy a game, I always consider if I'm going to play the game enough to make it worth it. Traditionally, I say to myself that if I play the game enough that it comes out to about $1/hour, It's worth it. $1/hour is very cheap entertainment.\n\nThat being said, I bought the 4-pack for this game while it was on sale, since some of my friends wanted it, as well. reviewText:
Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball is a fast paced instagib first person shooter, filled to the brim with flashy lights, disco awesomeness, robots on rollers playing dodgeball. That wasn't enough to make you buy this game?

PROS
Mechanics are really simple. Move over or click dodgeballs to pick them up.  Press shift to go faster. Press space to jump.
Click to throw dodgeballs. Hold down to throw further and faster.  Click incoming dodgeballs to catch them. That is literally it. Easy to learn.

Fast paced first person shooting. There is almost always a engagement around the corner to get stuck into.

Rewarding first person shooting. You'll feel awesome after landing a 360 noscope while flying through the air while on a 12 killstreak.

Friendly community. There will be that guy though.

Hard to get angry over. As a angry person, the frags are fast enough to not get mad over, unless it's a BS wall reflect, no one likes those :P

Good gamemodes. From the standard Capture the Cube and Team Deathmatch modes, there is also the Superball and
even a Basketball mode.

Good Bots to play against.

A wide amount of powerups!

FREAKING DISCO DODGEBALLING ROLLING ROBOTS.

Cons.

Small userbase. This is the biggest killer- a multiplayer game with no people to play it is not a multiplayer game. Do your part and help fill up the community.

Not many maps. This will be adressed soon, with a custom map editor, but I tend to stick to 3 or 4 maps. Plus, there are only 9 or so maps.

Some internet issues, nothing major.

RATING.
9/10

Solely held back by it's lack of a community, despite the fact it's better than 9/10 other modern shooters which claim to be next gen.

reviewText:
Okay. First thing's first. I'm not going to say that this game is life-changing or breaks the boundaries between videogames and art, or that it is even an incredible game...but that's not a bad thing. Just because this game doesn't break any new ground or pose a philosophical question, doesn't make it a sh**ty game. Modern media has created this idea that for a game to be respected, it has to make people view the world in a new light. Well, guess what? This is Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball. It's a game about robots on roller skates, often with moustaches, zipping around a disco with flashing lights and electro music, throwing balls at eachother. It hasn't provoked any reaction in me to make me go; 'Dear God!!! My life has a new meaning!!!'. Instead, it made me say; 'Ohh I'm gonna kill this skate-riding robo-sunnuffab**ch' (this was actually a genuine reaction). I like this game. It's fun. It's quick. But the best part about this game's fun-ness, is the fact that it's stupid. Goat Simulator, is stupid. It's funny at first (the amount of time I found Goat Sim funny for can be measured in themtoseconds), but it's not fun. RR-DDD is impressive in the amount of pros it has, despite the strong overtones of stupidity. It's tight controls and fun visuals have given me some good times. It's a little pricey, and a price drop or a sale might be necessary before it's entirely worth investing your money in, but don't let the price stop you if you like an FPS which requires a decent level of tactical skill (I'm looking at you Call of Duty). If the price is too much for you personally, try it out with a friend who already owns it. It might not be your cup of tea. As I say, it requires some tactical practice which may not be something you want in your robot related disco-shooters. However, if you're not a fan of tactical strategy games and like some fast-paced fun, I recommend this game greatly, along with a few games like Awesomenauts (easier) or Ratz Instagib (much harder). In conclusion, I give this game an 8.5/10. It's cool, but is lacking in areas which I won't go into, because I really don't want to put you off. It's fun, and you should give it a go. Why the heck would you listen to me anyway? I'm a random dude off the internet.
Finally, I don't think that this game is incredible or brilliant, but that's okay. You know why?


Because it's a game about roller-skating robots in a f**king disco.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty damn awesome. Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball has an amazing soundtrack. Not only does it fit what is going on in the game, it really pumps you up and gets you ready to crush nooblords in the ring of dodgeball. The controls are excellent when you get a hang of them, and you can really get sweet kills when you combine your jump and boost correctly.
This game also feels incredibly rewarding. Getting a kill feels awesome. Catching a ball feels awesome. Catching a ball and then getting a guy behind the person who threw the ball at you is awesome. Getting killed and then getting a mid-air kill on the person who killed you feels amazing. I've experienced this in bots alone.

This game is tons of fun. But the community is very small at the moment. This isn't really a bad thing though. You will recognise a lot of people if you play on public servers often. I haven't met a single person that has a negative attitude. But, sometimes you cannot find a server with people in it and have to play with bots.

The bots in this game aren't the average bots. The easy bots can be a challenge even after you play this game for a while. The bots are getting worked on often, and this has gave us the result of challenging bots. The bots actually use teamwork, like passing the ball to you or someone in need, or protecting somebody that is completing and objective in some game modes like Capture the Cube.

There are also a lot of game modes, with more going to be released. One of the ones I like is Score Battle. In this game mode you have to rack up a certain number of points for your team (or yourself if it's free-for-all) by getting points for killing other players. You get more points for doing crazier skill shots, such as a Helicopter, or a Dunk.

This game is just good. Real good. Before I said don't buy it until the community grows. Now I say support this game and Developer (https://twitter.com/82apps). They both deserve the support. This game is incredibly fun, and will only get better. As of now, I only have 3 hours played. This will definetely increase. Buy it, love it, and then finally remember it's full name.

EDIT: Updating at the release of the Arcade mode. This game has done nothing but get better and better. Buy it now before it's price gets increased. If your friends get in on this game with you, it's INCREDIBLY fun. Powerups, maps, modes, and more have been added and I love it.

reviewText:
Re-writing this review now that it's out of Early Access, and I've had time to come back to it to see what's changed.

What is it?
It's a simple arena shooter with one-shot projectile kills.

Pros?
+Great soundtrack
+Well designed AI
+Simplistic, well implimented art style
+Decent level design
+Fun, especially with friends
+Good visual options
+So much potential for satisfying trickshots
+Great announcer
+Decent single player modes

Neutral?
+Small but dedicated online community
+Lan support exists, but is super finicky
+Steam inventory support is there, but adds nothing to the experience
+Cosmetics exist but add nothing
+Custom soundtrack support exists, but is only for .wav and .ogg files (No MP3)
+Workshop support exists, adds nothing to the experience

Cons?
+Terrible netcode, no west coast servers
+Impossible to make competitive worthwhile
+Bad visual optimization

Overall still a good time, new updates are still coming out too, so the server problem may be fixed.

reviewText:
I didn't opt into Early Access for this. In fact, I had only heard of it once it got out of Early Access and hit the Steam Store on the front page. When I saw it, I immediately purchased a 4-pack solely because of the trailer video.

What's this game about? Dodgeball! You throw a ball at your target and they're out! Or, if they catch it, you're out. What does this mean in the game? You die. Plain and simple. Then you respawn and do it all over again. It's not that simple, however, because there's Trick Shots and a Brake key. Trick Shots net you more EXP for your unlocks and Points on Score Rush, while the Brake key stops you from moving. You should remember these to make the best of them.

I have 46 hours on record from the time of this post. I have no regrets with buying the 4-pack even though my friends don't play it much anymore. This game is THAT good. I'm even far enough to say that this is my new favorite FPS game.

I used to play TF2, but once this game showed its face, I quickly threw TF2 aside in favor of it. Not just because of the fact that hitscan doesn't exist (I'm terrible with hitscan), not because it's simple, but because at it's core it's FUN. TF2 stopped being fun, and this game filled the void TF2 had left me with.

I beat Arcade Mode once, I can trump Horde Mode pretty well, I'm pretty good at playing pubs on multiplayer, but that doesn't mean I'm a master at it yet. The gameplay ability of some of the higher-leveled players are godly, so if you think this game's got a lack of options, you've got a lot to learn. However, this isn't to deter you. The community from what I've noticed is mostly friendly and willing to chat a bit during the match. You might even get some pointers if you ask.

Multiplayer's not perfect, due to latency with the servers, but it's enjoyable if you're ping is good.

I haven't done everything in this game yet, but for what it's worth, I'm having my fair share of fun. I fully recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game in support of games that are compatible with Linux. That being said, I didn't buy it on a whim. It seemed like a fun arena type game to kill some time with. Which it is. RR-DDD is a very simple but easy to pick up game that will have you hooked for quite a while.

There are different modes with team based play, and FFA options so the variety that is available makes things interesting. The core mechanics are nice too. If you've ever played dodgeball in real life, it's the same thing. There are also various power-ups to get, which change your strategy slightly. The bots in a match can be challenging, which is nice.

As for a couple of downsides: This game seems to be from a very small operation development-wise. So updates may come a bit slower than other games. Also, sometimes the ball doesn't register as a hit when you clearly see it bounce off the opponent on your screen. Lastly, servers are hosted by players on their local machine. This means that since there aren't a ton of people playing, there aren't many servers to play on. When there are, the quality of the connection varies based on the host's connection speed.


All in all a great game. I would definitely recommend buying it if it goes on sale for any amount.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is still in Beta? IDK, but boy it sure feels like a completed flash game. Never have I had the amazing feeling of throwing balls and balls flying toward my face (not a joke). The games controls feel a little strange at first and when I say that I really mean you'll get used to the controls in under 5 minutes of gameplay. It actually feels smooth and responsive to your every input via keyboard. The colorful lights and AMAZING soundtrack or BGM is probably my favorite part of the game. it makes sence for a game about Robots and Dodgeball. The game offers a nice selection of game options allowing your dodgeball matches to go any which way. Normal Dodgeball, Score Attack, Basketball, Survival, Racing, etc. There are special kills you get for pulling off unique throws, such as the longshot kill, the helicopter kill, quick shot kill, a basic killing spree, aeriel kill, and most importantly: The Catch kill. The hardest things you will deal with in this game is the following:
1) Trying to catch someones ball (like in real Dodgeball) You must click your mouse at the EXACT MOMENT its about to hit you, otherwise you die. Seems Legit.
2) Jumping, you feel floaty but you eventually adapt to it.
3) Seizures, yeah make sure you play at a safe distance from your moniter, and play with the lights on or turn off some of the video options, I nearly got one but no biggy.
4) Music, Just listen, you will enjoy it, I'm 99.9% sure you will.
To conclude, Robots + Dodgeball + Pretty Colors + Awesome Music = Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball... And I love it... http://82apps.bandcamp.com/album/robot-roller-derby-disco-dodgeball-the-soundtrack

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The reviews of this game overwhelmed me with its positivity and I knew I had to get it right away. When I finally got it, I went right into the training and 5 minutes later I played my first game.

The game is simple. Very simple. Mastering your shots and angles is difficult, but with enough experience you get really good.

I played for an hour already and it flew by.

There is one issue, and that's the mechanics. You're sliding around a lot (intentional), and the jump is pathetic.

Even with those, this game is a perfect example of how early release should be and it's super fun!

reviewText: Crazy First person DODGEBALL!!!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
ROBOT ROLLER-DERBY DISCO DODGEBALL!

R.R.D.D.D.

Now I don't like the review games until I've played them for quite some time, but this truly is something special. Essentially a twitch shooter in the vein of Quake, Unreal, with a bit of RIchochet-y vibe thrown in (where's Richochet: Source GabeN??), this color drenched, electrictronic dance music stuffed masterpiece worth everyone's attention.

I love dodgeball. Who doesn't? Maybe I'm in love with this game just because as a chubby child I was always picked last for the game in P.E. and this is a way for me to live out my childhood. Regardless, this game is about an intense, over the top dodgeball match involving robots skating around on weird unicyle wheels while bright colors and music pulse continously. The game even follows all the standard rules of dodgeball; you can catch balls, bounce balls back if you're holding a ball, and during elimination modes you even get your teamates back in by catching the ball. There are plenty of game modes, from standard FFA and team deathmatch modes, to capture the flag and a basketball-like hoop mode. Surprisingly enough for a multiplayer focused game, the single player is pretty fleshed out, including various challenges and boss modes to get you warmed up for the multiplayer.

Dodgeball fits into the twitch based shooter genre like a pair of well worn jeans. The balls travel at a pretty slow rate compared to projectiles in other video games, so there is definitely a large amount of skill involved on leading and hitting each target. In addition to this, the afore-mentioned unicyle wheels make it more difficult to maneuver around instead of the standard WASD. However, after some practice you'll learn to use the movement system to your own advantage, hoping around and out-juking your opponents. When you land a badass trickshot by jumping over your opponents head, avoiding his mis-aimed toss, and slamming your ball into his face. That's amazing. When you strafe sideways, catch an opponents ball and jump into the air, spinning around to nail his buddy in the side.That's really freaking amazing. The game is chock-full of moments like this.

Don't take my word for it, try out the free demo in the store page. Within ten seconds you'll see what I'm talking about. My main fear is the viability of the long term multiplayer community, but so far, a game of this quality will have hardcore fans that will stick around for a long, long time. I will admit I was skeptical seeing the game's ridiculously overwhelmingly positive reviews on steam. But they were all correct. This game is amazing.

reviewText:
One of the most entertaining games in my library.

It's fast, intense, silly, and awesome. It's one of those games that is amazing in small doses. Play a couple matches every once in a while, and it's great. Play it more often and it's kinda frustrating.

In the multiplayer mode, which I imagine would be the most popular, I end up in games where half the teams are bots. While I normally like this feature, the bots are just way too accurate, and can be frustrating. This is most noticeable in Hoops, where the bots will get the ball, and make insanely fast and accurate shots into the hoop the moment they're able. I've also gotten stuck a small number of times, but other than that, it's been bug-free for me.

I feel this game is for fans of multiplayer first person shooters that grew tired of the immature crowd that ruined Halo, CoD, and Battlefield. Those games may be more polished, but it's not by much. And they take themselves too seriously, which is great for 14 year olds, but those of us with some gaming experience tend to enjoy the silliness factor of gaming a bit more.

Overall, this game may not get as many hours played as other games like Skyrim or Cities: Skylines, but I'm glad I have this in my library. It's a blast to play a couple matches every now and then.

Highly recommended

reviewText:
This game is addictive. Like, really really addictive. Gameplay consists of controlling a robot that you can customize and going into a disco skate park and throwing dodgeballs at other robots or completing the objectives of the other game modes. The basic mechanics are just like dodgeball itself.
-Go find a ball.
-Catch one thrown at you.
-Dude who throws it is out and/or(I dont play the team modes alot) a teammate comes back in.
-Another ball thrown at you.
-Block it.
-Throw it at dude.
-Miss because you keep thinking you have a gun instead.
-Realize you play too much Doom.
-Rinse, repeat.

Normally when it comes to multiplayer only games like this I get bored very quickly. But a few things keep me coming back. Some of the levels have a great design with multiple levels allowing attacks from above or a well place shot from below. And with physics coming into play you can find yourself easily flying in the air and throwing a ball at a faraway target and scoring an awesome kill prompting the announcer to yell mid-air" or "top-gun". Everytime you get a kill through a trick-shot
date: the announcer says the name and not gonna lie
recommended: picking up a ball then immediately throwing it at a guy with "quick-draw" popping up feels pretty badass. And to top it all off the music is just plain awesome
hoursPlayed: getting your adrenaline pumping for some awesome dodgeball action. However their are only around 10 tracks in the game so I recommend getting a few more from the workshop.\n\nTheir are about 10 multiplayer modes with most being able to switch from free for all to teams. There is also an arcade mode for singleplayer where you play increasingly difficult levels
voteText: buying upgrades and fighting bosses until you become president of the galaxy. If you lose all your lives however
helpfulPercent: you start all over. Along with that
votesHelpful:
their are 4 challenge modes that have tasks such as a basic survival mode and a mode where you are invincible and need to rack up as many points as possible. There are also offline bot matches to play which is where I've racked up a majority of my 10 hours playtime. Online is also pretty good. Even with my ♥♥♥♥ internet surprisingly. The netcode I had read about before must have been patched or something because I was able to pull off trick shots online just as well.

Pros
-Fun Skill-based gameplay
-Multi-leveled arenas are awesome
-Awesome Quake inspired announcer
-Trickshots feel awesome to do
-Music
-Music...again
-Not a grey and brown shooter...or loadouts(sorry I had to rip on modern shooters)
-Moustaches

Cons
-I sometimes get caught for a second on walls or rails
-A kill cam might be good to see some pro-strat kills
-The flatter maps are a little meh. Their great at first but levels like Temple are awesome
-The hats area of customization is empty at first...I really want a top hat and monacle

Misc
-There are modifiers. But I only use the big head mode. The rest I feel would just kinda ruin it. Like low grav. Don't do it. But meh they don't detract from the overall product

Conclusion: Buy it. Lose your life. Worried about purchasing without liking it? Get the demo. Review not funny enough? Well fuddle duddle look at my icon. Smile.


Moustaches"

reviewText:
TLDR below

Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball: a unique name for a unique game. I've played some good games, some bad games; I've played games for long periods of time, and I've played games for a few minutes before dropping them forever; and somehow, this game is a shining monument to what a game can be.

The game itself is pure arena-FPS bliss, with the fun new twists a dodgeball theme would bring. You can choose to weave through a storm of murderous projectiles, or you can drop your own and bring demise to your foes by catching. Various game modes bring on entirely new styles of play: care is required to not die in elimination, while throwing caution to the wind to make a spectacular kill is totally acceptable in score battle. Powerups can turn the tide of battle if you use them correctly and can get you killed if you don't. The rolling movement is slightly difficult to acclimate to but definitely works to help the flow of the game. And of course, it wouldn't be an arena shooter if you didn't have an announcer stating your helicopter kills and your killstreak.

However, the community and dev are what make the game truly outstanding. The community, albeit small, is full of great people willing to help you on your quest to dodgeball greatness or just chat. Bitter rivalries and strong friendships amongst veteran players make the game almost feel like a sport. Erik, our fabulous dev, keeps the updates coming many months after the game's release, through having a kid and working on a new project. He posted a post-mortem of the game a year after release, outlining the development process, the games strengths and drawbacks, and his plans for the future (link at bottom if you want to read it). Shortly after this, he dropped the games base price from 15 USD to 8 as part of an ongoing attempt to fix one of the game's major problems: the lack of players. He's constantly in the forums answering questions, looking for bugs to patch, and just trying to make everyone have a great experience.

At this point I must implore you, reader who is considering this purchase: do the community, the dev, and most importantly, yourself a favor; buy this game.

TLDR: great mechanics, great community, great dev, great purchase!
Link to post-mortem: http://www.82apps.com/DiscoDodgeball/blog/disco-dodgeball-postmortem.html

Edit: Totally forgot about robot customization. Robot customization and trading/market is good if you're into that sort of thing but is not necessary.

reviewText:
Hipster name, but the game works. Simple dodgeball simulator, with robots.

It weights little, the gameplay is easy to get into: you pick a ball, load the shot, shoot it, if it hits, you get a frag.
You also can do a (small) jump, and a (small) sprint.
Has powerups, such as returning ball (more useful than it sounds), jetpack, longer sprint, bigger ball, and similar. Not game changing, but can spice up the gameplay.

As far as I played, there was no situation of some player hogging up a cool powerup and winning the match this way: death is the great equalizer.
Everyone gets destroyed and often, the respawn time is almost null, maps are tight. This provides for frenetic action.

Small hiccup would be the movement, it's not fluid, but clunky.
Your jumps are really small, you can't run really fast, sometimes you keep going even though you're not pressing anything: for all intents and purposes you're controlling a vehicle.
Robot on wheels to be exact, not an fps character, so forget bunnyjumping, crouching or covers, you've got a limited set of movements and you're expected to make the best out of them.
Flaw or feature, that's for you to decide, but it's still something you'll have to get used to if you plan on plaiyng properly.

There's a leveling up system, and you get drops that you can use to craft better skins for your character, a way to keep interest going after you've played all the maps and tried all the modes.
Speaking of that, the game doesn't really offer lots of diversity: regardless of the variations, you're still throwing balls at robots in a symmetrical arena with colors flashing to disco music.

I'd compare this game to ratz:instagib or rocket league, it's a fast arena game, that will prove really amusing for the 10 to 20 minutes you'll be playing it. But gets dry if you try to dedicate more to it. Not that you can't, and the game encourages you to, but you've already seen all it has to offer. been there
date:
done that".


When it's on sale for 5$ or less
hoursPlayed: as a 5$ title.\n15$ wouldn't really recommend

reviewText:
Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball is one of the best games I have ever played that is not a Valve Inc. game.
Why should you get this game?
It is widely unknown, which always angers me. It is a skill based dodgeball tournament style game which relies on physics and control to win. There are so many options for single player that is amazes me. You can mess around with physics and many other features. The difficulty of the bots is very balanced and it is easy to progress skill to a peak.
I can go on for hours about this game, but I would rather be playing it for hours. The music selection is awesome. I recommend downloading the soundtrack. You can also play the game by uploading your own music to listen to as you venture the neon maps.
As I was saying before, there are so many options in this game as well as types of objectives. Think of 5th grade gym class. Then imagine each kid being a neon robot on a wheel. Then imagine this game of dodgeball is in a black room with lights and music as if you were in an amazing adults only disco club. That sums up the gameplay portion pretty well.
There are many options for lag. This game works well in a window and is easy to make adjust to your needs. Overall, definately get this game on sale. Even then, you should just get this game whenever. $10.00 or less is an excellent price because you will get a bang for your buck. It is one of those games you can play for a long time without getting bored because of all the options you could change as the player.
The only disadvantage is that is not being updated so often and community maps should also be an option. It also is a very small community so online mode is sort of annoying to have to wait so long. I love the attacks, achievements, and everything else. This is my example of a 10/10 game.
~thedubmark

reviewText:
One of the most entertaining games in my library.

It's fast, intense, silly, and awesome. It's one of those games that is amazing in small doses. Play a couple matches every once in a while, and it's great. Play it more often and it's kinda frustrating.

In the multiplayer mode, which I imagine would be the most popular, I end up in games where half the teams are bots. While I normally like this feature, the bots are just way too accurate, and can be frustrating. This is most noticeable in Hoops, where the bots will get the ball, and make insanely fast and accurate shots into the hoop the moment they're able. I've also gotten stuck a small number of times, but other than that, it's been bug-free for me.

I feel this game is for fans of multiplayer first person shooters that grew tired of the immature crowd that ruined Halo, CoD, and Battlefield. Those games may be more polished, but it's not by much. And they take themselves too seriously, which is great for 14 year olds, but those of us with some gaming experience tend to enjoy the silliness factor of gaming a bit more.

Overall, this game may not get as many hours played as other games like Skyrim or Cities: Skylines, but I'm glad I have this in my library. It's a blast to play a couple matches every now and then.

Highly recommended

reviewText:
This game is addictive. Like, really really addictive. Gameplay consists of controlling a robot that you can customize and going into a disco skate park and throwing dodgeballs at other robots or completing the objectives of the other game modes. The basic mechanics are just like dodgeball itself.
-Go find a ball.
-Catch one thrown at you.
-Dude who throws it is out and/or(I dont play the team modes alot) a teammate comes back in.
-Another ball thrown at you.
-Block it.
-Throw it at dude.
-Miss because you keep thinking you have a gun instead.
-Realize you play too much Doom.
-Rinse, repeat.

Normally when it comes to multiplayer only games like this I get bored very quickly. But a few things keep me coming back. Some of the levels have a great design with multiple levels allowing attacks from above or a well place shot from below. And with physics coming into play you can find yourself easily flying in the air and throwing a ball at a faraway target and scoring an awesome kill prompting the announcer to yell mid-air" or "top-gun". Everytime you get a kill through a trick-shot
date: the announcer says the name and not gonna lie
recommended: picking up a ball then immediately throwing it at a guy with "quick-draw" popping up feels pretty badass. And to top it all off the music is just plain awesome
hoursPlayed: getting your adrenaline pumping for some awesome dodgeball action. However their are only around 10 tracks in the game so I recommend getting a few more from the workshop.\n\nTheir are about 10 multiplayer modes with most being able to switch from free for all to teams. There is also an arcade mode for singleplayer where you play increasingly difficult levels
voteText: buying upgrades and fighting bosses until you become president of the galaxy. If you lose all your lives however
helpfulPercent: you start all over. Along with that
votesHelpful:
their are 4 challenge modes that have tasks such as a basic survival mode and a mode where you are invincible and need to rack up as many points as possible. There are also offline bot matches to play which is where I've racked up a majority of my 10 hours playtime. Online is also pretty good. Even with my ♥♥♥♥ internet surprisingly. The netcode I had read about before must have been patched or something because I was able to pull off trick shots online just as well.

Pros
-Fun Skill-based gameplay
-Multi-leveled arenas are awesome
-Awesome Quake inspired announcer
-Trickshots feel awesome to do
-Music
-Music...again
-Not a grey and brown shooter...or loadouts(sorry I had to rip on modern shooters)
-Moustaches

Cons
-I sometimes get caught for a second on walls or rails
-A kill cam might be good to see some pro-strat kills
-The flatter maps are a little meh. Their great at first but levels like Temple are awesome
-The hats area of customization is empty at first...I really want a top hat and monacle

Misc
-There are modifiers. But I only use the big head mode. The rest I feel would just kinda ruin it. Like low grav. Don't do it. But meh they don't detract from the overall product

Conclusion: Buy it. Lose your life. Worried about purchasing without liking it? Get the demo. Review not funny enough? Well fuddle duddle look at my icon. Smile.


Moustaches"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEasily one of the best games that you can casually play. From the cover of this game, the name sounds a little wonky, the music only sounded good in the trailer, and it looked a little amusing. Little did I know that this $10.00 game was one of the best casual FPS games that I've ever bought. If you were ever the kid who really liked dodgeball in gym class, this is the game for you. I can't tell you that I've never felt so badass as I have playing this game (well, I can, but when you hear MID-AIR CATCH" announced by the movie trailer guy

reviewText: Robot Roller Derby Disco Dodgeball has been a fantastic success while in Early Access and it is great to see it get a full release.  This game has a quirky physics engine that makes the seemingly easy game of dodgeball rather complex and fun to master.  An amazing community has developed around RRDDD which makes the multiplayer experience that much more enjoyable.\n\nThis is one of the best titles to have come out of Greenlight and the development has been a resounding success.  Robot Roller Derby Disco Dodgeball is a steal for the price.  Buy it and lose yourself in it.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just about as much fun as you can reasonably ask for out of any game. Brings me back to gym class in elementary school and adds an amazing twist with arena-style maps.

Incredibly funky soundtrack by Adhesive Wombat that's worth a listen in its own right.

Developer is super friendly and interacts with the community fairly often. I even had a chance to play a couple games with him while the game was still in development.

This game is a brilliant example of what Unity Engine games can and should be.

I'll be completely honest and say that my favorite part of this game is the announcer. He has some incredible one-liners and really brings a neat feel to the game.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Heard about this game over a year ago on a stream and bought early access immedietely because it sounded hilarious and amazing.  It is both.

Fantastic music, the lighting engine is quite good and fits well with the game. Some lag on launch day depending on who's hosting, but that's to be expected.  I'm so happy to see this game finally launch, because this will be a go to for a few hours of fun for many years as long as people are still around playing it.

Gameplay is a blast and controls pretty well.  Some floatyness in jumping, but it is intended. Mutators available for play and a single player mode that is still a lot of fun, but where it shines is multiplayer. Very friendly community of helpful players, and generally just a great time to hang out with people and play.

tldr; Unreal Tournament with dodgeballs. Buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far after 3 matches I am enjoying it and finding players, which is surprising! While I'll try to keep this short there's one or two thing I feel I should cover for potential buyers so I'll split this into sections.

Aesthetics:

Everything in this game takes a simplistic tron theme, I.e a large use of neon primary colours against various shades of grey. While everything in general does look nice, it seems currently that the text, levels, and GUI all seem a bit too blurry, but not so blurry that it becomes unplayable. While the game does have some video options, at this stage most importantly including resolution and an FOV slider, there is definitely room for improvement. I.e anti-aliasing, antistropic filtering.

The Player:

This is where it gets interesting. Initially I was put off by the character design not realising how it effects the gameplay. You play as a smiling unicycle robot with a moustache, and there is limited customization that in its current stage allows you to pick a colour and moustache type. It turns out the design does have a drastic effect on the gameplay, as you move around kind of like you were on a bicycle with a few extras. You can boost with shift which recharges over time and hold the jump key to jump higher, the faster you turn the slower you go, and acceleration over time is a factor, which will be slowed down when you pick up dodgeballs, even more so if you charge your shots. While I personally think the player should have some more air control this style of movement in an arena shooter is a lot of fun.

Gameplay:

In it's simplest form, this game plays like a typical deathmatch shooter with the twist of guns being replaced by instant kill dodgeballs, which can ricochet off of the environment and be charged for higher speed, although charging shots will slow you down and make you much easier to hit, dodgeballs also have drop off that varies depending on the speed that they are thrown. Dodgeballs can also be caught if you are lucky and passed to teammates in need. However (and while I have yet to play these) there is a surprising amount of game modes, including a horde mode, demolition derby, and a mode where you have to shoot through hoops to score points. There is a lot of variety for a day one early access game. For any UT fans out there, this game announces when you go on killing sprees, and will also commend you for airshots and long distance shots. While this game does emphasise multiplayer, if you can't find players, any empty slots will be filled with bots to play against while you wait for people to join.

Levels:

At the time of writing there are 7 arenas to pick from, while they are all aesthetically similar, the variation comes from the geometry within the arena, i.e a level may emphasise the use of pillars, ramps, or simply open space like classic dodgeball. While the designs are simple, they facilitate the nature of the game perfectly. When you respawn which only takes a few seconds, you respawn in a room with a forcefield that will save you from any enemies, you will also recieve a few seconds of spawn protection to prevent the enemy camping your base.

In Conclusion:

All in all im going to say so long as you are a fan of classic arena shooters, especially with a few twists, and so long as you can find players to compete against. This is worth buying, especially with its discounted price. Although I would say that $10 would be about as high as I'd pay for a single copy and I will be waiting for bigger sales down the line to buy extra copies for friends. This games strengths lay with its means to facillitate the fun of classic arena shooters with some new takes on the genre.

reviewText:
For my full video review please check out http://www.thegametutor.co.uk/videos/game-tutor-grades/150315_game-tutor-grades-robot-roller-derby-disco-dodgeball

Don’t let the garish look and childish title fool you robot roller debry disco dodgeball is by far one of the purest and most competitive FPS’s I have ever played.

I am not the best FPS player but this game is so simple and fun it really doesn’t matter. The premise is as a roller skating robot in an arena filled with disco music you must throw dodgeballs at each other.

This makes the game a one hit kill skill fest. There are a few powerups but I found when playing generally when going for the powerups this put you in a vulnerable position and they rarely helped instead the focus of getting a ball and lobbing it at your opponents was all that was needed.

The realy gratification in the game comes when pulling off some incredible piece of ball throwing that you wanted to happen but never ever though would work…. It’s that same feeling if you’ve ever thrown a basketball in real life from a massive distance and it’s against all odds and expectations landed in the hoop….. its an intoxicating feeling that doesn’t stop being powerful when you pull off one of these kind of shots.

Most of the time you are frantically gathering balls and chucking them for all your life… a mixture of pure skill and throw and hope yet this never becomes about luck and when you arew hit you always know it was your fault.

The fact you are on roller-skates also makes movement fairly tricky which adds to both the difficulty to throw and evade. Bring able to catch and block balls also adds to the level on skill much like you would in a game of realy dodgeball…. In fact playing this has given me the want to grab some friends a bunch of rollerskates and dodgeballs and give it a go for real….

Disco Dodgeball includes online multiplayer as well as AI-controlled bots plus a surprisingly deep single player arena mode for this kind of title.

There are quite a few different modes and having put in quite a few hours already I am still hungering for more. I cannot recommend this game enough and defiantly recommend picking it up on steam now. So remember the 5 Ds of dodge ball is  dodge, duck, dip, dive, and dodge.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Robot Roller Robot Derby Disco Dodgeball

Writing this on patch .371

Game is alot of fun, especially with friends. I've played this game for awhole lot of time and to me it just never gets old. Game is worth the price and if you got three friends the four pack is also worth it, thats what I bought. Keep in mind this game is in early access and there are some latency bugs but thats about it.  These problems arn't game breaking at all and probobly will be fixed at some point in the future.

This game has the potential to grow into the next big game, the game that all the streamers play and the one thats always on the front page of steam. I met and spoke with the creator of this game at 2014's PAX East, although we didn't speak for awhile he seemed to be a very dedicated man who would do anything to see this game florish.

10/10

I met and spoke with the creator of this game at 2014's PAX East, although we didn't speak for awhile he seemed to be a very dedicated man who would do anything to see this game florish.

10/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is one of the best first person multiplayer games I have ever played. Keep in mind I have played call of duty, Halo, Destiny, Titanfall, Team Fortress 2,the Counter strike series, and garry's mod. This is one of the best fps games because it is easy to learn to play and you can easily play it with freinds, easily customize matches, no extra places to spend money, as well as different modes to suit your play style that is both fun with yourself, but even better with friends. The Powerups this game has will also boost the fun level to new hights if you so choose to use it.Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball has an amazing soundtrack that you can listen to for hours and best of all you can have a balls to the wall match that has all the powerups in the game on all at once, that combonation makes for some pretty epic games. In conclusion this game is super fun, and the more people play, the more fun it gets. The price for this game is amazing if you want a great Fps that you can play with your friends and also play by yourself. There are also constant updates that make the game get better and better, this combined with a great dev that listens is a killing blow to garbage broken overpriced fps's that are basicaly rinse and repeat every year. I would buy this game again if I had to, but since I don't I'm going to go play it now!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nothing feels so satisfying as doing a 360 spin mid-air and hitting your friend in the face with a dodgeball.

Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball is a great example of multiplayer arena games just being so dang fun.  It strikes a great balance between skill and chaos.  The disco part of this game gives it so much personality.  Music is used extremely well to keep the game exciting and fast paced.    Visuals keep improving, but the unique neon lights and dance club feeling are great.

As an Early Access game, it continually gets updates and improvements.  The dev is quite active in the game and any sites about the game.  You might even play him in a match!  I bought this much earlier and it has only improved from then.  However the only downside is that player base can be somewhat small.  This isn't a major problem because of AI but also because you're only in a room with 6-12 other people.  I recommend the 4-pack, or getting your friends to buy the game too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Experience on Linux:

+ Works. (I had problems with nvidia drivers 334.21, there's a patched version, 334.21-2 for most distros, that fixed the problems for me, although it might have been the latest game update as well)
+ Developer communication is always appreciated!

The game:
Much in the same way that ID Software introduced the arena style with Q3A, this game follows and creates a competitive game where you... I guess you control robots on rollerskates. I'll just take for granted that you know how dodgeball works. The controls are a bit akward at first, I wouldn't say bad, but they definately add a challenge to the game. This game works perfect along side some cold beers during a LAN weekend. It's one of those games you play intensely for 30 minutes when you need a break from the seriousness of online, competitive gaming. If you like fast, team based gameplay you should check it out.

Score:
3/5

reviewText: Yes, it's a good game, but all these people who say there are no cons are completely fooling themselves. The multiplayer lag situation is totally out of control, and what's worse is that you can't even see ping in-game. At any given time there are maybe a couple hundred people online, and the consequent lag means the entire catching mechanic is worthless: You will never, without extraordinary luck, catch a ball, because their client will register a hit before you even see them throw.

reviewText:
This game is a quick, very fun, very colourful, and very worthy game to play!

Rounds are quick shooting matches 5 v 5 which are usually over in less than a minute. Don't let the time frame fool you. It's a lot more skill involved than you might think. It's great for those who get an fps itch and just happen to want a light fast game to play when you're in a rush. Though you might get caught up in playing more than just a few rounds.

The soundtrack is great. It's not extreme into any of the electrical music genres so no one will be groaning over too much dub step or not enough of it. The aesthetic of the game definitely makes you feel like you're playing a round of dodgeball in a really crazy rave club.

Turn up the bass and shoot some ball!

reviewText: Really good game if you are looking to spend some time playing around with some friends! I don't have many hours but so far this is a really fun game. This game has some cons but the one that really stood out to me was the pricing.\nLike I understand that this game is fun and all but $16?!? A little overpriced in my opinion but oh well. I recommend getting this on sale! I got a four pack for $14 so I can play with some of my buddies and I do not regret the purchase!!"

reviewText:
As with Super Acrobatic Rocket Powered Battle Cars, the game had a lot of potential but was poorly executed, only difference is that Psyonix picked up their ♥♥♥♥ and made Rocket League.

What I am saying is that the games idea is a orginal and could captivate a lot of people but a few things need to be added:

-Shorter name
For the same reason I didn't get SARPBC the name is annoyingly long which turned a lot of people away from the game

- Better UI and HUD
The UI and HUD (are they the same thing) give off a bad feel, making it more silky and fancy would really add to the         game

-More music
After a while, It gets repetitive

- Ranked
I know damn well I wouldn't be playing Rocket League or Csgo as much if they didn't have ranked the casual feel   doesn't sell very well for me

Add that to a new game and you got yourself a seller like Rocket League (I use Rocket League commonley as an example because it also had a game before it that's name was super long so no one bought it but it had potential)



Bonus potential names for the game:

Disco Dodgeball
(I am not as creative as i thought)
voteText: 8 of 21 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Personally, I find the controls to be awkward (for both controller and keyboard, and even after changing the buttons to try and suit me better). Nothing personal against the game, but it frustrated me to the point where I couldn't play it for more than 20 minutes. I do have friends that seem to like it, but I couldn't stand it, so it's a no from me.
voteText: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I bought this game and then requested a refund. The online play ruined this good idea. If I went to catch a ball I was already dead. If I went to pick up a ball, the guy next to me already had it. This made for an infurating time. Also, as others have mentioned, I didnt like one multiplayer mode so I quit to get put into a different game. Three times I reconnected to the same exact match. One match? Laggy as hell? (PS - I know what acceptable lag is (NONE). I can go play TF2, POE, and any number of games with no problems) I feel the lag issue is possibly ineffecient software programming.\n\nIts a shame, cause the game idea was fun.
voteText: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The online games are fun for a little while, but unfortunately the online community is rather small. Most of the time there are only 2 servers up in Europe, and no servers elsewhere (in my experience). Currently there are no servers up in Europe.

The single player mode is annoying. It reminds me of the worst bits of old school games that you have a limited amount of lives and you have to beat 10 levels with them. If you die you have to start from scratch. No saves, no level codes, no nothing. I thought that was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t already back in 1991, and I do not wish to see these features reintroduced in modern games.

Disco Dodgeball is a decent distraction for a couple of hours, but I would not recommend it.

reviewText:
******** EDITED / UPDATED *********

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I want to recommend this game. I love the idea, the fun free-for-all smash 'em up bang around dodgeball havoc. I want to recommend this game. And perhaps in time, I can. That time has not come.

I think its all about the controls. They need to be insta-intuitive, and they are not... Not on controller (which is how you should play this game), and they are not with k/m. And even the config to tweak the controls is buggy.

There is so much going on, it seems the bots are having a BLAST... i only wish I could jump in and join them. I got this on uber sale, cause I just saw the current asking price of $15... OMG! No way ever. Its not even a $5 value YET.

**********

UPDATED:

Suddenly im getting all these salty comments on my honest review. I took the liberty of deleting them, but Im not sure the deleting of salt is local or global, so I shall respod in kind.

If these reviews of my review are ANY indication of the horrible community that plays this game, as other bad reviews suggest it is, good luck in life.

One claimed i lost all credibility" due to my complaining abut the controller functions. Brotha.... dont you worry

reviewText:
I've played this game for well over a year, and I absolutely love this game. I really do. It has so much potential. But the developers of the game made the mistake by putting it in a bundle. An entire new wave of players came in, which isn't bad. The bad thing is, the wave of players that came into the game are absolutely garbage.

Here's a list of what these new players tend to do:

1.) Namecalling
2.) Put downs
3.) Bad sportsmanship
4.) Threats

I would recommend this game before the game was bundled, but I just can't like this game because the community is just not as good as it was before.

reviewText:
So here's the deal, I sold a couple CS:GO skins cause this game was in the featured list on Steam's main page. Bought this game after reading a TON of great reviews and watching a few notable Youtubers review this game positively as well.

Let me tell you, this game is VERY FUN, and I can see myself dumping quite a bit of time into it. However, NOBODY PLAYS IT. Across the entire planet, there were only 2 servers online at all. Each server had about 3 players in it total including myself.

Yes throwing and catching the dodgeballs in this game is quite a lot of fun, and mechanically sound. It's just a ghost town of a game, and who wants to play an arena shooter game like this with NOBODY.... Well, the answer is nobody.

If this was a free game I would say Download it for sure, but honestly there is not a single reason for dropping $15 + Tax on this, even if the game could be a gem.

Honestly I wish I could get a refund, it's too bad.

+1 for a great soundtrack
+1 for fun gameplay
+1 for relatively well programmed BOTS

-15 for being wayyy overpriced for what it offers
-1,000,000 for having no players

reviewText:
Played it less than 3 hours.
The game doesn't worth 15 bucks.
Picked it up for 5 bucks on a sale.
This game spent a weekend.(Which was also not that fun.)
The game is basically dead.
Most of the time was spent with friends who bought it with me so we can play. (And I am happy we did because then it would be a total waste of money.)
I was so happy about this game, but I ended up sad.
It doesn't seem to give me the feeling I thought I'd feel from seeing the trailer.
The pepole I played with (Who weren't my friends.)
Were ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
I was on a match with a friend. And we wanted to make a 2v2.
As time passed we had someone joining the match. (Finally.)
I don't know how much time he played the game but he was very good. He started to make these little funny comments, which just turn into very annoying ones.
He first started with this comment.
Pro: Okay,who wants to lose? (Spectating at the moment.)
Noobs (Me+Friend): *laughing*
-
*after some time of try-harding and getting our ♥♥♥ kicked*
-
Me: I think I'll move to my friend's team, since you are better than both of us. But I think It'll be easier for us.
Pro: Go ahead, be my guest.
Noobs: *laughing*
-
After some time he started making this into a cruel trolling.
Which was very not sportive and annoying. We both just left the match angry.
After sometime we tried doing the same thing. And guess what? That guy comes in again. And he brought another friend.
Both of them were pros.
It was unstable and not fun.
And when I finnaly managed to kill one of them, all he said was:
Have fun
date: because this is the last time I'm letting you win me."\nThis just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off right away. I tried to complimant him every round. They were good. But this wasn't fun. I mean
recommended:
not because they were better. Only because they were very unsportive and childish. They made this game even worst.
Later on I realised they were almost the only pepole playing and there was no point of making any friends.
And one more thing.
THE GAME IS REPEATIVE.
Doesn't matter how many gamemodes there are it is all the same.
The only one thing I kinda feel needs to be pointed out as good
is the amazing soundtrack.
Okay maybe when in-game it feels like there is no difference if there was only one song. (When playing the music is even more repeative from the game itself.)
But I did like some of the tracks.
I really don't know how to end this review now.
Let me just say.
In my opinion it is a very repeative game

reviewText:
No local multiplayer. I bought this game under the apparently misguided impression that there would be local multiplayer, but sadly I was disappointed because this could be a fun party game.

Very twitchy controls when using a controller, and menu input is rather frustrating due to this fact. It's basically impossible to turn down the controller sensitivity because the game doesn't handle input from a controller very well.

This game also apparently does not like it when more than one controller is connected to the PC at once. It doesn't crash, but the game will only accept input from only the most-recently-connected controller.

If you're looking for a fun pick-up-and-play couch game you should probably skip this one. This is much more suited to being played online at a desk with a keyboard and mouse.

reviewText:
I'd like to rate this game up but I can't do it in good conscience because of a lot of issues that make it frustrating to play the game.

Yes, you'll get your money's worth out of it, but if you're playing Multiplayer, it's going to be very inconsistent. If you're expecting a competitive game, this sadly isn't the best game due to that.

Because this is a Not Recommended review I'll be posting the negatives before the positives (but after going over the basics) as they are the biggest breakers of the game, and also the fact that most people looking for the negatives of the game will want to see them first. A lot of these issues will be less impactful for newbie players.

I have a list of negatives and positives but it's too long to fit in a Steam review, so I've put it in a pastebin file. http://pastebin.com/r7TGpmS6

The basic gist of it is that there are 3 horrible mechanics in the game (block/shield/powerups), unbelievable lag, but also has a lot of other good things about the game that evens out the score. Here are the first 3 worst negative" paragraphs:

An edit: There is a custom mode creator for the game where you can turn blocks
date:
shields and powerups off. This is good!

-- NEGATIVES --

The worst issue of the game is the Multiplayer. It's peer-to-peer
recommended: so you'll get blatant host advantage. This gets especially worse if the Host player has a high ping to the master server. The host will get uncatchable balls (because you die before you even get in catching range)
hoursPlayed: balls that can get catched even after 2 bounces and maybe worse. However
voteText: due to P2P
helpfulPercent: the host is not the only problem.\n\nYou will also get more teleporting balls than usual
votesHelpful: a longer delay between kills
votesTotal: every player teleports around the map[gfycat.com]
votesFunny: and so on. This delay is incredibly bad and I play with 30-40 ping. I literally haven't found a worse experience since Contract Wars.\n\nBut even with a regular host ping
commentsCount: there are still aspects that make it a very infuriating experience. You will get a LOT of teleporting balls
column16: and this is due to Unity physics being non-deterministic. While this may not be something the developer could fix easily
column17: it is still part of the game and has to be mentioned. What this means for you is that every time a ball strikes a surface
column18: it could bounce off to the left side of the arena for one person
column19:
and could bounce off to the right for another person.

-- OVERALL --
Latency and some mechanics will turn the competitive crowd away. The game is great for single experiences but frustrating for anything more.

6 / 10"

Honestly I love the idea and as a solo experience it is really fun. But as a game advertised for a multiplayer community it falls short. The Netcode is terrible to the point of being unplayable. Lan parties exist and I assume this would be a great time during one... and as a solo experience you will probally get 20 dollars of fun out of this but as a overall product it fails and is a huge missed oppurtunity.

reviewText:
You roll into the arena. Pulsing lights and thumping music set the tone of the match. Dodgeball. You pick up the ball at your feet and hurl it at an enemy on the other side of the arena. He catches it and you explode.

Respawning, you zoom back into the arena. You head for a ball, but the enemy intercepts you. You try to boost away, but your boost meter hasn't fully recharged, so you can't manage the speed. He pegs you and you explode.

Return to the arena. You can't see any balls immediately, so you jump up in order to locate one. There's one over there. You spin your wheel as hard as you can, but your trajectory is completely unchangeable once airborn. The enemy easily leads you and you explode.

You roll back into the arena. Glancing around reveals that there are no balls nearby for you to pick up. An enemy rounds a corner, ball in hand, and chucks it at you. You try to catch it, but your crosshair wasn't within the few pixels allowed, so you explode instead.

You see a ball ahead of you as you leave spawn again. Your wheel nicks a ramp on your way there and sends you floating through the air. Helpless again, the enemy hits you and you explode.

You respawn to see a lone ball by the spawn room. You pick it up just as the enemy enters your view with a ball of his own. You launch your ball quickly to get first strike. He blocks it with his ball and smashes you with his own. You explode.

You reenter the arena and grab another ball. The enemy approaches with a ball -- the same situation as before. You elect to hold onto your ball to block his shot this time. He hurls his ball at you. You weren't looking at the ceiling, though, so his ball flies right over yours and connects with your face. You explode.

You roll into the arena and explode. You didn't see the enemy this time because of all the flashing lights.

You trudge back into the arena, infuriated with how little you can do. You attempt a more tactical approach this time, avoiding the enemy and staying evasive until you have the upper hand. After a few minutes of boosting and hiding, the opportunity arrives: he has no ball in his hand and you're approaching his flank. You wind up to throw...

and his teammate pegs you and you explode.

You slam the escape key six time before your mouse lands upside down on the desk.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Maybe the realities of latency make it impossible to deliver an accountable experience. In its current state you WILL see the following things happen:
Pick up a ball only to have it vanish from your hands a second later
Chase the ball after a score in hoops mode only to see it teleport across the arena
Attempt to catch an enemy ball thrown right at your chest and succeed only 50% of the time in spite of spamming M1These problems don't happen in single player (offline) mode, so if you don't mind playing against just bots, this gets a thumbs up.
This would probably be great at a LAN party, if those were a thing anymore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been putting off getting this game for way to long. Grabbed it the other day after playing the demo (which includes the multiplayer btw). All I can say is I havn't been happier with a game purchase in a long time. So heres a quick break down as to why.

Pros:
-The music is fantastic lots of high energy up beat techno that feels right at home in this game (Also the levels will pulse with color in time with the music.
-Controls are very responsive and simple. also Your robot will keep moving until you break or change direction. allowing you to look around with changing direction.
-Very polished, More so then most finished AAA games.
-Free demo that allows you to play multiplayer
-Full custom keybinding
-Tons of levels
-Tons of modes (TDM, CTF, Keep away, derby race, basketball, horde, endless tournament and more)
-Mustasches
-Loads of trick shots and combos
-Excellent dodgeball mechanics
-Power ups (boomerang ball, fireball, big ball, jetpack, lazor ball and so on.)
-Is 'joy inducing' a feature i can point out?
-All the other excellent stuff i can't even think of

Cons:
-Your not playing it yet

I have 600-some games on my steam acct. This one, This one right here is one of my new favorite games of all time. You are doing yourself and Gaming as a medium a huge disservice by not buying this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game more than most of the other games I've ever bought. That alone should show how fun this game can be.
If nothing else, this game is one of the best FPS-type games I've ever played with it putting most players on a comparatively even level from the beginning (skill in the game not withstanding), and you can keep it that way in your game if you want the power-ups and other options turned off (or if you want everyone to have some of them all the time). Additionally, it's one of the few FPS games I've played where part of the fight is over the ammunition you have and it is also one of the few that encourages trick shots.
The community for this game is also the nicest FPS community I've ever seen. And, if multiplayer isn't your thing, there are several single-player modes, including standard matches against bots (good for practice) and specialized endurance modes.

reviewText:
Dodgeball is fun.
Dodgeball whilst controlling unicycle robots and raving simultaneously and having a monstertruck announcer hype up everything you do is insanely fun.

On a more serious (as serious as you can get for this game) note, the game is well built and very well polished overall. There are several game modes ranging from Deathmatches and dodgeball game Elimination to 'Super Ball', where one of you has to keep a golden dodgeball from the other team and keep it away from them as long as possible, whilst your teammates protect you.

There are numerous singleplayer modes as well, despite it being mutiplayer focused (as you would expect) and the bots are surprisingly good (or I just suck :P).

In terms of skill, the balls move quite slow as projectiles (relative to most twitch-reaction FPS games) and so there is a fair bit of skill leading shots. Not only that, in point-based games, extra points are given for ricochet shots, mid-air shots etc. etc. Also, it does take some getting use to the jump (hold down longer for bigger jump) and the fact you are uncontrollable, movementwise, when airborne (I hope you have decent momentum buddy!). But its not that bad to adjust, and the feeling you get when you do something awesome, intended or not, not matter how much it has happened before, is euphoric. And then you get the monstertruck guy massively hyping you up. Because he's awesome too.

There are also powerups, which do various things such as homing shots, jetpacks, fireballs (balls can't be blocked or caught) etc. Because the game wasn't exciting/silly enough already.

Its truly is great. Its silly appeal (robot dodgeball robot rave) doesn't seem to wear off, and regardless, it is a well built FPS game. It can appeal to those who are casual or competitive, because everything is a 1-hit KO.

Also, robots have mustaches and glasses.

tl:dr version: Robots. Dodgeball. Rave. Fun. Monstertruck Announcer. Hype. Awesomeness. Euphoria.

I really really hope this game grows a good multiplayer scene, because it deserves it 100%. The dev recognises this and has already tried to help it along as much as possible, with easy to join multiplayer matches.

RRDDD (Robot Roller-Derby Disco Dodgeball) everyone.

(Side note: I have an Alienware laptop: So my laptop follows the colourscheme of the game. My laptop raves whilst running the game. Completely superfluous, but great nonetheless.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game where neon colored robots with moustaches roll around and try to blow each other up with dodgeballs.
10/10

Actually though, theres so much about this game that's great. It plays like a shooter, trying to eliminate other players to gain dominance over a battlefield, but it's so much more than just your run-of-the-mill FPS. The music is great, the stages are creative and really fun to play on, the power-ups add a zany twist to the gameplay that you can't find anywhere else.

On the surface this game seems like a big joke (which it kind of is), but once you actually start playing, you realise that it's an actually a really fun, viable game (RRDDD for eSports anyone?), in which you have to be able to predict your enemies every move, as you can only carry one ball at a time and have to scourge the map for a new one if you miss, and taking one blow kills you, no questions asked.

Not to mention the community, which is great. You don't see the type of toxic people that show up in games like LOL and most FPS's, just a bunch of good guys having a good time with the game. The lead dev is constantly online, talking to the players and taking their advice on what they think should be in the game.

I give this game a 9/10 for the great times it's given me and my friends.
